Why wouldn't they be able to?
Yes they can, and quite well in my opinion.

1.) If you're an atheist.
 
 2.) If you don't want to believe in the entire Bible.
 
 3.) If you're agnostic.

Calligirl,
 Why do you consider atheism and agnosticism to be religions?
 I think that Christianity, religion, and evolution can co-exist. I know Christians that believe in evolution and who also believe in the Bible. They think that God directed and guided evolution.

Why do you consider atheism and agnosticism to be religions?

 
 religion: commitment or devotion to religious faith or OBSERVANCE
 
 religious: relating to or manifesting faithful devotion to an acknowledged ULTIMATE REALITY or diety
 
 Therefore we can conclude that atheism and agnosticism are religions.
 
 
I think that Christianity, religion, and evolution can co-exist. I know Christians that believe in evolution and who also believe in the Bible. They think that God directed and guided evolution.

 
 I didn't say that they "couldn't co-exist". What I said was that they could only co-exist under certain circumstances:
 
 1.) If you're an atheist.
 2.) If you don't wan't to believe in the entire Bible.
 3.) If you're agnostic.

Well, maybe you can say that atheism is a religion since they believe in the ultimate reality that God does not exist. I don't think you can say that agnosticism is a religion since they don't either believe or disbelieve in the existence of God. Does lack of belief constitute a religion?

I don't think you can say that agnosticism is a religion since they don't either believe or disbelieve in the existence of God. Does lack of belief constitute a religion?

 
 Their "ultimate reality" is that some higher authority may exist. It's still an "ultimate reality" to them. Definitely a religion.

1)... 2)... 3)...
 
 
 Why don't you just sum it up with "If you're not a fundamentalist Christian"?
 You also fail to consider Christian agnostics.
 
 
religious: relating to or manifesting faithful devotion to an acknowledged ULTIMATE REALITY or diety
 
 
 Atheism does not show 'faithful devotion' in any ultimate reality or deity. It is the LACK of a belief (the belief in gods).
 Your definition of religion is thin.

Why don't you just sum it up with "If you're not a fundamentalist Christian"? You also fail to consider Christian agnostics.

 
 I think that's a good definition. What is a Christian agnostic? (Never heard of them.)
 
 
Atheism does not show 'faithful devotion' in any ultimate reality or deity. It is the LACK of a belief (the belief in gods). Your definition of religion is thin.

 
 Yes, they do show a faithful devotion to the ultimate reality that there are no gods. You're an atheist, aren't you?
I'm not atheist or agnostic, and I believe in the whole bible...but I believe the two coexist.

 An agnostic believes gods cannot be logically known (ie require faith). One can believe in the Christian god at the same time.
 
 
Yes, they do show a faithful devotion to the ultimate reality that there are no gods. 
 
 
 That's not a faithful devotion, it's a logical conclusion. 
 
 
You're an atheist, aren't you?
 
 
 Of course.

I'm not atheist or agnostic, and I believe in the whole bible...but I believe the two coexist.

 
 Genesis 1:12 "The land produced vegetation: plants bearing seed according to their kinds and trees bearing fruit with seed in it according to their kinds."
 
 Genesis 1:21 "So God created the great creatures of the sea and every living and moving thing with which the water teems, according to their kinds, and every winged bird according to its kind."
 
 Genesis 1:25 "God made the wild animals according to their kinds, the livestock according to their kinds, and all the creatures that move along the ground according to their kinds."
 
 Genesis 2:21-23 "So the LORD God caused the man to fall into a deep sleep; and while he was sleeping, he took one of the man's ribs and closed up the place with flesh. Then the LORD God made a woman from the rib he had taken out of the man, and he brought her to the man. The man said, 
 
 "This is now bone of my bones 
 and flesh of my flesh; 
 she shall be called 'woman,' 
 for she was taken out of man." 
 
 How do you explain these verses?

"kinds" is meaningless

 
 kind: Race; genus; species; generic class.
Oh ok. By that definition, your god was wrong.

Oh ok. By that definition, your god was wrong.

 
 A perfect example of why Christian fundamentalismm and evolution can't co-exist. If God is wrong, then the Bible is wrong. Evolution contradicts the Bible, plain and simple.

A perfect example of why Christian fundamentalismm and evolution can't co-exist. 
 
 
 I don't think anyone argued that Christian fundamentalism was able to co-exist with reality.
 
 
If God is wrong, then the Bible is wrong. Evolution contradicts the Bible, plain and simple.
 
 
 It contradicts a literal interpretation of the Bible.

I don't think anyone argued that Christian fundamentalism was able to co-exist with reality.

 
 Please stop making statements that have nothing whatsoever to do with the debate at hand. We're not talking about Christian fundamentalism and "reality".
 
 
It contradicts a literal interpretation of the Bible.

 
 And...?

Please stop making statements that have nothing whatsoever to do with the debate at hand. We're not talking about Christian fundamentalism and "reality".
 
 
 Sure we are. Creationism vs all the sciences (including the biological Theory of Evolution) and reality. 
 
 
And...?
 
 
 And few people hold that view anymore.

Sure we are. Creationism vs all the sciences (including the biological Theory of Evolution) and reality. 

 
 Last time I checked, it was a debate about religion and evolution co-existing. Not a debate about Creationism vs. "science" and "reality".
 
 
And few people hold that view anymore.

 
 Few people literally interpret the Bible anymore? I'd like to see the statistics on that.
Ummm...what's to explain, none of those contradict with theistic evolution, at all.

According to recent (2000) Gallup poll (Gallup is a fundamentalist christian), about 27% of all American adults believe in biblical inerrancy. That is down from about 38% in 1973. Even among Southern Baptists, only 57% believe in a literal reading of the Bible. While most Americans consider themselves religious, church attendance is down among most religions. However, since 1942 Roman Catholics have gone from about 21% to 25% of the population. Of course, Roman Catholicism is the largest Christian sect in the Unites States, as well as the world. During the same time, Protestants have gone from about 75% of the population to about 55%. 24 to 30% state that they attend church weekly and 54 to 58% claim less than once a week attendance. Gallup also finds that Americans overstate their church attendance by about 70%.
 
 The numbers on Roman Catholic are from before the recent clergy scandals.

Last time I checked, it was a debate about religion and evolution co-existing. Not a debate about Creationism vs. "science" and "reality".

 
 Well, stated that way, there is no problem with religion and evolution co-existing. Many evolutionary biologists are religious. Dr. Kenneth Miller of Brown U. is a practicing Christian and a respected evolutionary biologist. He engages in debates from time to time with creationists and ID proponents. There is little problem with the theories of evolution and most main-line religions around the world.
 
 The real debate is between a minority of United States fundamentalist christians and science in general. You have seen on this board that even though the theories of evolution are biological, several creationists have insisted that somehow there is a grand theory of evolution that includes the origin of the universe, the galaxies, the solar system, the planets, the earth, and life on earth. Typicaly, creationists claim that they don't oppose science but only evolution - and by that they mean cosmology, astronomy, astrophysics, planetary physics, biochemistry, geology, most of physics (relativity, quantum mechanics, thermodynamics), genetics, molecular biology, population genetics, embryology (evo-devo), paleontology, paleoanthropology, and on and on. What is not opposed is trivial and limited that data upon which scientific theory is built, not the theories.
 
 So to answer the question can religion and evolution co-exist? Without question. Evolutionary scientists do not study matters outside the domain of science. Science is naturalistic - methodological naturalism - and cannot observe and study the supernatural. The supernatural cannot be quantified. I have yet to see an equation that represents the power of God. That is not to claim that things outside of science do not exist or are not valid and important. It is just that science is not the proper tool for the study of such matters. Questions of faith and morals fall in other domains - theology and religion, for example.
 
 Can creationism and science co-exist? Probably not. But the problem is not with science. It is with creationism. Creationism establishes its conclusions before any evidence is examined based on "divine revelation." The problem arises when science, without regard to religion, uses the scientific method to arrive at conclusions that cannot be reconciled with creationist conclusions. This makes science the evil work of Satan, and it means that scientists are trying to escape responsibility to a god based on primitive mythology.

thistown:
 
 
Ummm...what's to explain, none of those contradict with theistic evolution, at all.

 
 So you don't believe that God took a rib from Adam's side to create woman? 
 
 Genesis 2:21-23 "So the LORD God caused the man to fall into a deep sleep; and while he was sleeping, he took one of the man's ribs and closed up the place with flesh. Then the LORD God made a woman from the rib he had taken out of the man, and he brought her to the man. The man said, 
 
 "This is now bone of my bones 
 and flesh of my flesh; 
 she shall be called 'woman,' 
 for she was taken out of man." 
 
 lurch:
 
 I don't have time to quote everything you said so I'll just comment on it. 
 
 You guys keep saying that "of course, religion and science can co-exist perfectly". When did I say that they couldn't? I simply said that fundamentalist Christianity and evolution could not co-exist. Catholics are a perfect example, they do not believe that they can pray to God directly. They believe that they have to pray through a priest, saint, etc. That is not fundamentalist Christianity. You keep trying to make an argument out of something that I am not arguing about. 
 
 You also say that creationism cannot co-exist with "science". You say that evolution is science. If creationism can't co-exist with evolution, then how can there be any evolution believing Christian fundamentalists? (thistown for example.) Creationism, by the way, is used very broadly. It is simply the study of how we were created, just as evolution is the study of how we "evolved". They can be used to mean the same thing if you are a Christian who believes in evolution.
 
 BTW, science isn't the "evil work of Satan". It's man's way of trying to explain something so that they don't have to believe in something that threatens the way they enjoy living. (The Bible.)

BTW, science isn't the "evil work of Satan". It's man's way of trying to explain something so that they don't have to believe in something that threatens the way they enjoy living. (The Bible.)
 
 
 That's the worse definition of science ever.
 
 
Creationism, by the way, is used very broadly. It is simply the study of how we were created, just as evolution is the study of how we "evolved". 
 
 
 No, Creationism is the specific idea that the creation story in Genesis is literally true (creation ex nihilo, direct creation of organisms, global flood, etc). It is false.

Catholics are a perfect example, they do not believe that they can pray to God directly.

 Yes, they do.
 
They believe that they have to pray through a priest, saint, etc.

 No they don't. Your remarks are so silly that they are stupid. Do you ever educate yourself about facts before you comment?
 
 
Creationism, by the way, is used very broadly. It is simply the study of how we were created, just as evolution is the study of how we "evolved".

 
 No. Creationism was a reaction in the late 1800 to the ideas of Darwin and Lyell. The major voice of anything that could be called creationism was George Frederick Wright, a Congregationalist Evangelical minister in Vermont. Fundamentalist christianity was the first voiced by A.C. Dixon with a series of 12 booklets published between 1910 and 1915. These and other ideas were taken up by the 7th Day Adventist Church with the flood geology of George McCready Price. But while fundamentalism flourished, creationism didn't really take hold. Most fundamentalist christians were poorly educated and didn't encounter the ideas of science. Of course, the theory of evolution was not taught in our public schools at the time. There was a brief stir in 1925 with the Scopes Trial, but generally, fundamentalism and science never met. Until the launching of Sputnik when the U.S. realized that we were way behind in teaching science and math in our public schools. There followed a revision of the science curriculum that introduced such ideas as the big bang, the great age of the universe and of the earth, and biological evolution. As a result, Henry Morris adopted the ideas of Price, and essentially launched what became modern creationism.
 
 The word has come to mean a biblical literalist. Most Christians who believe in God the Creator are not creationists. They are able to see that Genesis is not scientifically or historically accurate. It is the mythology of nomadic herdsmen.
 
 Read The Creationists by Ronald L. Numbers. Numbers is a former creationist, the son of a 7th Day Adventist minister, and a professor of the History of Science and Medicine at the University of Wisconsin, Madison.
 
 
BTW, science isn't the "evil work of Satan". It's man's way of trying to explain something so that they don't have to believe in something that threatens the way they enjoy living. (The Bible.)

 
 No, it isn't. What do you know about what I believe? What hubris! When did God appoint you judge? Science is not a way to escape anything and it is not threatened by the Bible. However, science is threatened by stupidity.
He's right about the Catholic stuff. Fundamentalis protestants only use this to demonize them

Scholars theorize that the Hebrews got their creation story from the Babylonians and Sumerians since they have similiar creation stories. 
 
 Calligirl,
 You refer to Eve being created out of Adam's rib. That probably never literally happened. It also contradicts Genesis 1. In this chapter they were created together. 
 "So God created man in his own image, 
 in the image of God he created him; 
 male and female he created them." (Genesis 1:27)
 
 The creation story in Genesis 1 conflicts with the creation story in Genesis 2. In Genesis 1 man is created after the animals. In Genesis 2 Adam is created before the animals (Genesis 2:18-20). In Genesis 2 Eve is created after the animals (from Adam's rib). So were Adam and Eve created at the same time or separately?

Consider that if Eve were created out of Adam, literally, that Eve would be a clone. Eve would have had 1 X chromosome and 1 Y chromosome, just like Adam. Now I know that Calli doesn't understand that, but it is the difference in the X and Y chromosomes that determine gender - females have 2 X chromosomes and males have 1 X and 1 Y.
 
 So now I guess it becomes Adam and Steve.
 
 But no. Creationists claim that their god took the rib and miraculously changed 1 X chromosome in every cell to a Y chromosome. The question now becomes, why was the rib even necessary if there was going to be some sort of miracle anyway?
 
 So now there is yet another problem. Except for that pesky Y chromosome, Adam and Eve would have been genetically identical. That means that any given gene could have only 2 alleles (variants). Genetic analysis of the human genome has shown that on average, every gene has about 14 alleles, and these would have to have arisen in only 6,000 years. That's evolution at rates that no evolutionary biologist would dare propose.
 
 But wait! There's more! There are more than 3000 genetic diseases that have been identified down to the specific locus of a specific chromosome (I have seen various numbers reported between 3000 and 6000 - and more are being identified every year) in the human genome. How could they have all developed in such a short time - they are, after all, caused by genetic mutations (they are alleles of normal genes).
 
 So in answer to the question, "So you don't believe that God took a rib from Adam's side to create woman?" the answer is, certainly not. The very idea rings of mythology. When someone tells me that they believe this, I hear the banjo theme from "Deliverance" in the back of my mind. These are people who can claim to have made a detailed study of evolution with an open mind, and then state that evolution is a denial of their god. plink.plink.plink..plink..plink

lurch:
 
 What I meant by saying that they don't "pray to God" is that they don't believe that they can go directly to God to ask forgiveness of sins, etc. They have to "confess" to a priest in order to be forgiven. 
 
 Thank you for proving my point! (On the "Eve created from Adam" argument.) Thistown said that fundamentalist Christianity and evolution can co-exist. Obviously, by reading your post, they can't.
 
 Tim:
 
 Genesis 1:27 says that God created Adam and Eve. (I couldn't find the part about them being created "together".) No contradictions there.

Get the point?) Can you please read the verses more carefully before you say that they contradict eachother? Please?!?!

Whoa, whoa...I NEVER said fundamental Christianity and evolution could co-exist, I have no idea where you got that. I said Christianity and evolution could co-exist. Calligirl,
 Read the preceding verse. "18 The LORD God said, 'It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper suitable for him. 19 Now the LORD God had formed out of the ground all the beasts of the field and all the birds of the air. He brought them to the man to see what he would name them; and whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name. 20 So the man gave names to all the livestock, the birds of the air and all the beasts of the field. But for Adam no suitable helper was found." (Genesis 2:18-20)
 
 Kenneth Davis, in explaining these verses comments- "God creates every animal and bird to be man's helper. The man names them all. But the man doesn't find a suitable partner from among the animals." In verse 18 God uses the phrase "I will." This is not past tense and this is after Adam has already been created in verse 7. 
 
 
Genesis 1:27 says that God created Adam and Eve. (I couldn't find the part about them being created "together".) No contradictions there.

 They were both created on the sixth day according to Genesis 1.

There is a key difference between correct and believing everything in the Bible to be literal (take American (or was it Patriot) believes that ALL Old Testament law should be in effect today). That is fundamentalism. You're fooling yourself if you believe that people who aren't fundamentalists do not believe the bible is "correct". I think fundmentalism is a huge part of what is wrong with Christianity and the average non-Christian's perception of it.
 
 Anyway, again, I ask you which account of Eve. There are 2. One makes no mention of a rib. I believe that Genesis is important, but I think that it must be read and understood on a little bit more of an abstract an general manner than say, Mark.
 
 You can't bear to hear this, but Genesis is not infallible. It's a fact that it was written by 2 different groups of people and combined in Egypt in 90 AD. The book was not written as you read it today. It was passed down orally over hundreds of years before anyone ever bothered to write it down. Therefore, it's about 1/100th as important to me and my faith as the Gospels, which were written down by eye-witnesses at the spoken time. So yes, I believe that God created the world, but I believe his tool was evolution.
 
 I guess my question is, which account are you speaking of? You can't say "Genesis" because the book, the combination of Genesis, is man-made, 2 seperate and different accounts were forced together to make "Genesis". How do make the choice on which account you believe (the Jehovists or the Elohists)?

Read the preceding verse. "18 The LORD God said, 'It is not good for the man to be alone. I will make a helper suitable for him. 19 Now the LORD God had formed out of the ground all the beasts of the field and all the birds of the air. He brought them to the man to see what he would name them; and whatever the man called each living creature, that was its name. 20 So the man gave names to all the livestock, the birds of the air and all the beasts of the field. But for Adam no suitable helper was found." (Genesis 2:18-20)

 
 Okay, here is how it went: God made the animals. He said,"Hey, Adam needs a helper." He brought the animals to Adam to name. He couldn't find a helper for Adam. He then took a rib out of Adam's side to create Eve. This was done on the sixth day. God created them both on the sixth day, Adam first, then Eve out of Adam's side after he had Adam name the animals.

Anyway, again, I ask you which account of Eve. There are 2. One makes no mention of a rib. I believe that Genesis is important, but I think that it must be read and understood on a little bit more of an abstract an general manner than say, Mark.

You can't bear to hear this, but Genesis is not infallible. It's a fact that it was written by 2 different groups of people and combined in Egypt in 90 AD. The book was not written as you read it today. It was passed down orally over hundreds of years before anyone ever bothered to write it down. Therefore, it's about 1/100th as important to me and my faith as the Gospels, which were written down by eye-witnesses at the spoken time. So yes, I believe that God created the world, but I believe his tool was evolution.

 
 So you don't believe the entire Bible? Then you fit perfectly into the category of those who "do not want to believe the entire Bible".
 
 
I guess my question is, which account are you speaking of? You can't say "Genesis" because the book, the combination of Genesis, is man-made, 2 seperate and different accounts were forced together to make "Genesis". How do make the choice on which account you believe (the Jehovists or the Elohists)?

 
 The entire Bible is "man made". When you start believing that parts of the Bible are infallible, where does it end?

 Okay, here is how it went: God made the animals. He said,"Hey, Adam needs a helper." He brought the animals to Adam to name. He couldn't find a helper for Adam. He then took a rib out of Adam's side to create Eve. This was done on the sixth day. God created them both on the sixth day, Adam first, then Eve out of Adam's side after he had Adam name the animals.
 
 
 
 That interpretation is fine except that God says, "I WILL make a helper suitable for him." He hadn't made the animals yet in verse 18, but he created Adam in verse 7.

Originally posted by Calligirl 
 The entire Bible is "man made". When you start believing that parts of the Bible are infallible, where does it end? 
 
 
 As a Christian comfortable with their faith and reality.

I know "how it went", and no the two accounts are extremely different. You've been told you're entire life that the alternate account is just a "summary" because the majority of Christians don't want to accept the facts. There ARE inconsistencies and controversies in Genesis, it's quite obvious.

"You are to bring into the ark two of all living creatures, male and female, to keep them alive with you. Two of every kind of bird, of every kind of animal and of every kind of creature that moves along the ground will come to you to be kept alive." (Genesis 6:19-20)
 
 "Take with you seven of every kind of clean animal, a male and its mate, and two of every kind of unclean animal, a male and its mate, and also seven of every kind of bird, male and female, to keep their various kinds alive throughout the earth." (Genesis 7:2-3)
 
 So how many of each animal did God want Noah to take on the ark? Two conflicting versions of the Flood Story were combined- thus the discrepancy.

Calli,
 
 I'm wondering what it implies that God brought each of the animals to Adam and none of them proved to be a suitable "helper." What exactly does that mean, given the activities that seem to have been carried on between Adam and his proper "helper", Eve?

That interpretation is fine except that God says, "I WILL make a helper suitable for him." He hadn't made the animals yet in verse 18, but he created Adam in verse 7.

 
 He had ALREADY MADE the animals. "now the Lord God HAD FORMED..." not "now the Lord God formed..." See the difference? He already HAD FORMED the animals before he brought them to Adam. He made the animals before Adam. 
 
 
As a Christian comfortable with their faith and reality.

 
 The Bible contradicts "reality". So does heaven and hell. Once you start doubting parts of the Bible, the rest falls apart. Can you PROVE that their is a heaven or a hell? Can you PROVE that there are miracles? No! When you don't believe in part of the Bible, you might as well not believe in all of it.
 
 
I know "how it went", and no the two accounts are extremely different. You've been told you're entire life that the alternate account is just a "summary" because the majority of Christians don't want to accept the facts. There ARE inconsistencies and controversies in Genesis, it's quite obvious.

 
 I love how you guys say that because I've been "told something all of my life" that means that I'm blindly accepting it. How many of you went to public schools? Well, I can say that you were "told all of your life" that evolution was the way that everything came into existence. Basically you're saying that I was brainwashed...from my point of view, you were too.
 
 
So how many of each animal did God want Noah to take on the ark? Two conflicting versions of the Flood Story were combined- thus the discrepancy.

 
 The problem here is the translation from Hebrew to English. In Hebrew the translation was "seven pairs" in the English translation we wrote it as "seven". No contradictions there.
 
 
I'm wondering what it implies that God brought each of the animals to Adam and none of them proved to be a suitable "helper." What exactly does that mean, given the activities that seem to have been carried on between Adam and his proper "helper", Eve?

 
 What?!

He had ALREADY MADE the animals. "now the Lord God HAD FORMED..." not "now the Lord God formed..." See the difference? He already HAD FORMED the animals before he brought them to Adam. He made the animals before Adam.
 
 
 It says had formed because the narrative is in the past tense. However, the preceding line says "I will" implying he had not made them as of that point.

"How many of you went to public schools? Well, I can say that you were "told all of your life" that evolution was the way that everything came into existence. Basically you're saying that I was brainwashed...from my point of view, you were too."
 
 Well, I went to school in the backwoods so I was taught evolution for about an hour throughout my high school career. Why? Because the science teachers knew that self-righteous narrow minded Christians would crucify them. I read up on evolution with 18 years of knowledge on "Creationism", and decided that it didn't conflict with the God that I knew. Let me ask you this. How do you KNOW that Revelations is not to be taken literally, but that Genesis is?

It says had formed because the narrative is in the past tense. However, the preceding line says "I will" implying he had not made them as of that point.

 
 What he was saying is that he needed to make a helper for man. Not that he needed to make animals and then search through them for a helper. He already had made them. He looked for a helper but could not find one. (This stuff would be so much easier to explain in person.:))

Well, I went to school in the backwoods so I was taught evolution for about an hour throughout my high school career. Why? Because the science teachers knew that self-righteous narrow minded Christians would crucify them. I read up on evolution with 18 years of knowledge on "Creationism", and decided that it didn't conflict with the God that I knew.

 
 Evolution completely contradicts with the God that you know! Have we ever been able to explain (scientifically) the things that God has done? Have we ever been able to explain hell, heaven, angels, miracles, etc.? No. God is beyond our comprehension. 
 
 
Let me ask you this. How do you KNOW that Revelations is not to be taken literally, but that Genesis is?

 
 Why shouldn't Revelation be taken literally?

Calligirl,
 I don't think that you take all of the Bible literally.
 
 " Tremble before him, all the earth! 
 The world is firmly established; it cannot be moved." (1st Chronicles 16:30) 
 Do you actually believe that the Earth doesn't move? 
 
 "On the day the LORD gave the Amorites over to Israel, Joshua said to the LORD in the presence of Israel: 'O sun, stand still over Gibeon, O moon, over the Valley of Aijalon.' So the sun stood still, and the moon stopped, till the nation avenged itself on its enemies, as it is written in the Book of Jashar. The sun stopped in the middle of the sky and delayed going down about a full day." (Joshua 10:12-13)
 Joshua commanded the sun to stop moving around the Earth. Do you believe this?
 
 "And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to go into hell." (Mathew 5:30)
 Do you actually believe that Jesus wants us to cut off our right hand if it causes us to sin?

" Tremble before him, all the earth! The world is firmly established; it cannot be moved." (1st Chronicles 16:30) Do you actually believe that the Earth doesn't move?

 
 You are probably using the NIV version of the Bible. It is not the most accurate version because some of the meaning was lost in the translation. Here is the NASB version (much closer to the original meaning): 1 Chronicles 16:30 "Tremble before Him, all the earth; Indeed, the world is firmly established, it will not be moved." "will"= future tense. The earth itself is moving (rotating, orbiting the sun, etc.), but it "will not be moved" by something else. 
 
 
"On the day the LORD gave the Amorites over to Israel, Joshua said to the LORD in the presence of Israel: 'O sun, stand still over Gibeon, O moon, over the Valley of Aijalon.' So the sun stood still, and the moon stopped, till the nation avenged itself on its enemies, as it is written in the Book of Jashar. The sun stopped in the middle of the sky and delayed going down about a full day." (Joshua 10:12-13) Joshua commanded the sun to stop moving around the Earth. Do you believe this?

 
 Yes I do.
 
 
"And if your right hand causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to go into hell." (Mathew 5:30) Do you actually believe that Jesus wants us to cut off our right hand if it causes us to sin?

 
 He was using it as an example. He was saying that if something in your life causes you to sin, get rid of it!
 
 BTW, thanx for giving me the references to your verses! It is really annoying to have to search through the Bible to find verses that people quote without references.:)

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Can Evolution & Religion Coexist
